column5: OCLC, United States of America
column7: Increasing Community Access To Library Resources Through Online Visibility
column9: community engagement, library partnerships, web visibility
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Libraries reach only a small percentage of current and potential users through traditional channels such as their websites. This interactive program features panelists who will discuss opportunities to increase the visibility of libraries on popular websites and expand engagement with community members beyond established physical and virtual library locations.
column17: Libraries reach only a small percentage of current and potential users through traditional channels such as their websites. This interactive program features panelists who will discuss opportunities to increase the visibility of libraries on popular websites and expand engagement with community members beyond established physical and virtual library locations.
column18:
Libraries struggle to remain relevant and reach members of their communities in an environment of proliferating information sources. Studies have shown that libraries reach only a small percentage of current and potential users through traditional channels such as library websites because most people do not begin their research at a library. Instead, they usually turn to search engines and familiar non-library websites first when looking for information.

Recent events have highlighted the importance of community access to information and cultural heritage. While the Covid-19 pandemic has greatly increased demand for open and electronic resources, the racial injustice propelling the Black Lives Matter movement has underscored the work that must be done to create equal access to cultural material. Libraries are tasked with addressing social justice in their communities, and a necessary component of this is broadening access to library resources beyond the library’s physical boundaries, and beyond its existing patrons

In this program, panelists will discuss new ways librarians can connect with people in the non-library websites they regularly consult for information. They will demonstrate the success that partnerships with some of the largest consumer and education sites have delivered in increasing the visibility of libraries, and show how community members can benefit by being able to reach libraries easily from their favorite websites.

Panelists representing a cross-section of library types and sizes and commercial organizations will also discuss opportunities for partnerships that increase the visibility of unique special collections related to cultural heritage and social justice.

During this interactive program, participants will share their own approaches for engaging hard-to-reach information seekers in their communities and will have the opportunity to brainstorm additional tactics. Participants will leave the program with recommendations for new strategies to try when they return to their libraries.
column19:
Libraries struggle to remain relevant and reach members of their communities in an environment of proliferating information sources. Studies have shown that libraries reach only a small percentage of current and potential users through traditional channels such as library websites because most people do not begin their research at a library. Instead, they usually turn to search engines and familiar non-library websites first when looking for information.
Recent events have highlighted the importance of community access to information and cultural heritage. While the Covid-19 pandemic has greatly increased demand for open and electronic resources, the racial injustice propelling the Black Lives Matter movement has underscored the work that must be done to create equal access to cultural material. Libraries are tasked with addressing social justice in their communities, and a necessary component of this is broadening access to library resources beyond the library’s physical boundaries, and beyond its existing patrons
In this program, panelists will discuss new ways librarians can connect with people in the non-library websites they regularly consult for information. They will demonstrate the success that partnerships with some of the largest consumer and education sites have delivered in increasing the visibility of libraries, and show how community members can benefit by being able to reach libraries easily from their favorite websites.
Panelists representing a cross-section of library types and sizes and commercial organizations will also discuss opportunities for partnerships that increase the visibility of unique special collections related to cultural heritage and social justice.
During this interactive program, participants will share their own approaches for engaging hard-to-reach information seekers in their communities and will have the opportunity to brainstorm additional tactics. Participants will leave the program with recommendations for new strategies to try when they return to their libraries.

column16: The presentation will introduce the work underway at Pratt Institute and New York University on the Digital Preservation Outreach and Education Network (DPOE-N). Pratt and NYU took over DPOE from the Library of Congress in 2018, and with a grant from Mellon Foundation, is resuming operations on this important initiative.
column17: The presentation will introduce the work underway at Pratt Institute and New York University on the Digital Preservation Outreach and Education Network (DPOE-N). Pratt and NYU took over DPOE from the Library of Congress in 2018, and with a grant from Mellon Foundation, is resuming operations on this important initiative.
column18:
In 2018, the Library of Congress (LC) entrusted DPOE, its pioneering Digital Preservation Outreach and Education program, to Pratt Institute (Pratt) and New York University (NYU) to further develop and support it into the future. To build on this promise, Pratt and NYU are in the process of building DPOE-Network (DPOE-N). DPOE-N is a network of training resources available to cultural heritage professionals nationwide to enhance their digital preservation knowledge and skills with a significant outreach and recruitment component.

This presentation will introduce attendees to the work underway on DPOE-N. In July 2020, DPOE-N received a $600,000 grant from The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, which will allow it to continue development. This funding will provide for the creation of microfunding support for professional development for cultural heritage professionals. The funding can be used for workshops available from Pratt and NYU, but also from a larger network of professional development opportunities, such as available from the Society of American Archivists.

The funding will also have some funds allocated to emergency hardware support where staff at libraries, archives and museums who are facing budgetary shortfalls because of the COVID-19 pandemic can request money for hardware, such as hard drives for making secondary or tertiary copies of their data.

You can learn more about the project at dpoe.network.

BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)

column14: BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
column16: This presentation describes the metadata schema, content standard, and taxonomy guidelines created for Curationist.org, a crowd-sourced, multilingual aggregator of open access cultural content. Designed to accommodate multiple layers of metadata and to reflect Curationist’s progressive values, eventually, this collectively enhanced dataset will be available as linked open data.
column17: This presentation describes the metadata schema, content standard, and taxonomy guidelines created for Curationist.org, a crowd-sourced, multilingual aggregator of open access cultural content. Designed to accommodate multiple layers of metadata and to reflect Curationist’s progressive values, eventually, this collectively enhanced dataset will be available as linked open data.
column18:
This presentation describes the creation of a metadata schema, content standard, and taxonomy guidelines for Curationist.org, an online aggregator of Creative Commons, Open Access, and public domain content. Content is sourced from galleries, libraries, archives, and museums (GLAM). A team of curators contributes to Curationist.org by writing articles, providing context around images, videos, and/or cultural content pieces. The site is also open to community contributors who can add their own metadata.

Curationist’s goal is to build a space where art, cultural heritage, and knowledge are collaboratively produced by communities from around the world, in a way that is pluralistic in thought and practice. To that end, the schema, standard, and taxonomy guidelines are designed to accommodate multiple layers of metadata and to record their sources in multiple languages. They are also designed to support and facilitate Curationist’s anti-colonial, anti-racist, anti-ableist, feminist, and queer values. Eventually, this collectively enhanced dataset will be available as linked open data.

The presentation will highlight factors to consider in designing more inclusive and responsive data structures that provide for greater community access and contributions to our shared cultural heritage.

1: Harvard University, United States of America;
2: Yale University, United States of America
column7: ‘Time Capsule’ Archiving Through Strong Dark Archives (SDA): Designing Trustable Distributed Archives for Sensitive Materials
column9: delayed-release archival, digital preservation
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column14: BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
column16: Digital artifacts pose new challenges for delayed-release archiving. To protect our historical record for future generations, we propose Strong Dark Archives (SDA), a blended administrative and technical protocol for securing delayed-released archival materials among networks of libraries.
column17: Digital artifacts pose new challenges for delayed-release archiving. To protect our historical record for future generations, we propose Strong Dark Archives (SDA), a blended administrative and technical protocol for securing delayed-released archival materials among networks of libraries.
column18:
Archivists regularly contend with a wide range of security threats, including data breaches, inadvertent loss, and legal coercion by those hoping to make sealed records public. These threats are particularly salient when sensitive materials are donated with delayed-release conditions.

Trust in archivists’ ability to enforce such conditions gives donors the confidence to enter into the historical record materials that they might otherwise destroy. But as these materials are increasingly born-digital (and therefore hackable, convenient to exfiltrate en masse, and more easily corrupted), and as governments and private parties become ever more aggressive in their efforts to secure early releases, we must innovate in order to stand still.

To compensate for these new dynamics, we propose Strong Dark Archives (SDA), a blended legal and technical protocol for securing delayed-released archival materials among a network of libraries. SDA leverages modern cryptography and institutional agreements to coordinate access-control across multiple accredited archival organizations, providing broad resilience to data breaches, technical failures, and legal process. Through this distributed approach to security, SDA imposes meaningful friction on efforts to force the early disclosure of archival records.

Deploying SDA will require bringing together the expertise of archivists, lawyers, system engineers, cryptographers, and others. We hope that participants of DLF will be inspired to apply the SDA protocol in a wide range of use cases, including archival of personal papers, disinformation on social media platforms, and sensitive corporate materials. With the guidance of this community, SDA stands to introduce a new level of trust to delayed-release archiving.

column7: The Iowa Labor History Oral Project: Managing Oral History Projects in the Digital Age
column9: oral histories, project management, digitization, grants, partnerships
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: The Iowa Labor History Oral Project (ILHOP) is a critical resource for Midwestern and labor history. Now, as the project retools for the digital age, it faces challenges and opportunities of managing large digitization projects, demonstrating the extensive collaborations necessary to create, sustain, and make accessible long-term oral history projects.
column17: The Iowa Labor History Oral Project (ILHOP) is a critical resource for Midwestern and labor history. Now, as the project retools for the digital age, it faces challenges and opportunities of managing large digitization projects, demonstrating the extensive collaborations necessary to create, sustain, and make accessible long-term oral history projects.
column18:
With approximately 1,300 interviews, the Iowa Labor History Oral Project (ILHOP) is a critical resource for Midwestern history. Started in the 1970s as a collaboration between the Iowa labor movement, the University of Iowa Labor Center, and the State Historical Society of Iowa, ILHOP has grown into one of the largest, longest-running labor-focused oral history projects in the world.

Now, as the project retools for the digital age, it faces challenges and opportunities associated with managing a large oral history project over time. Since 2013, with the support of new partners and a series of national grants, project staff have collected hundreds of new born-digital interviews, digitized over one thousand analog interviews, made the digitized collection accessible online, and begun the process of transitioning a 2003 print index into a complete, expandable, and keyword searchable digital index.

While this recent work has greatly expanded ILHOP’s reach and significance, it has also created new challenges for project management. This presentation will focus on the shortcomings of controlled vocabulary for indexing and metadata creation. Both the structure of the 2003 index (developed for interviews focused on the 1930s-1960s) and LCSH terms have frequently been insufficient for describing the project as it has grown and evolved over time.

Our intention is to demonstrate the extensive collaborations necessary to create, sustain, and make accessible long-term oral history projects. Our audience is those of all skill levels interested in oral histories, historical diversity, and digitization project management.

column7: Using Wax and Jekyll to build minimal digital projects
column9: digital scholarship, web development, digital collections, programming, minimal computing
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: While a custom-built digital collection, exhibition, or repository can be a huge undertaking, it doesn’t need to be! This session showcases Jekyll and Wax as helpful tools for building digital scholarship projects minimally. We’ll explain the philosophy behind these tools, explore an example repository, and direct you to additional resources.
column17: While a custom-built digital collection, exhibition, or repository can be a huge undertaking, it doesn’t need to be! This session showcases Jekyll and Wax as helpful tools for building digital scholarship projects minimally. We’ll explain the philosophy behind these tools, explore an example repository, and direct you to additional resources.
column18:
“Minimal computing” is a paradigm for building digital projects that emphasizes building only what is needed, minimizing long-term maintenance and over-design, and maximizing ephemerality, accessibility, and justice. Wax is one tool that emerged from the Minimal Computing Working Group in order to empower the digital scholarship community to build digital collections minimally. This focus on ethics in technology and the low barrier to entry make Wax a great fit for library digital projects, and drew our attention as data visualization educators looking for a robust platform to host example data visualizations and their source datasets as part of the IMLS-funded Visualizing the Future Symposium project.

Wax leverages Jekyll, a static website builder with a native “collection” framework that ports nicely to digital scholarship collections. Building on top of Jekyll means Wax-based projects can be hosted publicly for free on GitHub. Wax adds functionality for metadata, image processing, and search and image gallery interfaces, allowing collection builders to focus on collection objects rather than software development.

In this 15 minute session, we will provide:

1. A quick conceptual overview of Wax as a minimal computing tool and how it relates to Jekyll

2. A deep-dive use-case demo of a Data Visualization Examples Repository, and

3. Highlights of other Wax examples and resources for learning more

This session will be useful to developers and collaborators on digital projects, as well as those who may be in a position to make referrals to researchers, students, and community members.

column35: We are excited to share the minimal computing values adopted by Wax, and will brief discuss the ethos of "maximizing justice" as a call to prioritize reducing barriers for marginalized communities in digital projects.
column50: Thank you for your work and your consideration!

column5: University of Houston, United States of America
column7: US Latino DH: Recovering the Past, Creating the Future
column9: US Latinx, archives, digital humanities, diversity, post-custodial archives, underrepresented histories, pedagogy, public humanities
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column14: BIPOC (Black, Indigenous, and People of Color)
column16: This panel focuses on the use of underrepresented US Latinx archives and digital humanities to reconfigure how we understand the past and imagine a more inclusive future through. The turn to the past allows to interrogate and rewrite/reimagine a US history where Latinx voices are not disregarded or erased.
column17: This panel focuses on the use of underrepresented US Latinx archives and digital humanities to reconfigure how we understand the past and imagine a more inclusive future through. The turn to the past allows to interrogate and rewrite/reimagine a US history where Latinx voices are not disregarded or erased.
column18:
This panel focuses on the use of underrepresented archives to reconfigure how we understand the past and imagine a more inclusive future. We specifically take into account the ways that US Latinx archives are often disregarded, erased, misrepresented, and misused. Not only are such archives overlooked, but their producers–who often identify as non-white and/or not along heteronormative identities, and write in languages other than standard English–are not considered to be legitimate parts of history. Turning to the past creates new ways of understanding US history by filling in the gaps and re-presenting US Latinx peoples as active participants and contributors to the social, economic, political, and cultural fabric of the nation.

The US Latino Digital Humanities program (USLDH) at the University of Houston draws from the rich archival collections at Recovering the US Hispanic Literary Heritage (Recovery) in order to make visible the legacy of Latinxs in the US. Recovery is an international program to locate, preserve and disseminate Hispanic culture of the United States in its written form since colonial times until 1960. The program has compiled a comprehensive bibliography of books, pamphlets, manuscripts and ephemera produced by Latinxs.

During this panel, we will discuss the types of materials available in the Recovery collections, the attention to ethical choices when dealing with underrepresented archives, and the critical interventions that can take place at pedagogical and research levels. We claim that the use of archival materials in the undergraduate classroom has the potential to create a student-centric understanding of public history. Our panel will focus on how prioritizing underrepresented archives shifts the perspective of history. We then examine the usage of Omeka class assignments in which students learn about metadata and consider how to describe items, especially those in languages other than English. We will describe how this type of assignment teaches students to crucially think about how knowledge is produced and who produces said knowledge.

Furthermore, the panelists will describe the active ways that Recovery/USLDH engages with the community to preserve and raise awareness of history. This includes postcustodial archives, community events, and public history initiatives that serve to involve community members and community historians in the preservation and sharing of knowledge.

column35: USLatinoDH serves as a great model for university to community work. We consistently work with the Latinx community in and outside academia to provide a secure space for archives but also to extend training and collaborations.

column7: The Migration Is The Easy Part
column9: Migration, Metadata, Workflows
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Recently, the University of Miami Libraries migrated from a locally-hosted instance of CONTENTdm. The actual data migration turned out to be the easy part. The hardest parts of the migration were all the processes surrounding the migration, and the COVID-19 pandemic presented additional challenges to adapting to a new system.
column17: Recently, the University of Miami Libraries migrated from a locally-hosted instance of CONTENTdm. The actual data migration turned out to be the easy part. The hardest parts of the migration were all the processes surrounding the migration, and the COVID-19 pandemic presented additional challenges to adapting to a new system.
column18: Recently, the University of Miami Libraries migrated from a locally-hosted instance of CONTENTdm to an OCLC-hosted instance of CONTENTdm in order to take advantage of technology updates and provide a better platform for displaying our diverse digital collections. The actual data migration turned out to be the easy part. The hardest parts of the migration were all the processes surrounding the migration: identifying content, ensuring content was standardized and uniform, adapting to new features, coordinating across the library, etc. The migration also presented opportunities to re-envision workflows, re-evaluate current practices, and revise best practices. The COVID-19 pandemic presented additional challenges to adapting to a new system, but allowed the implementation team to engage additional library staff in the migration process. Additional staff meant additional planning and training, but the effort was ultimately successful. This presentation will provide participants with a roadmap of the migration planning process and a perspective on the work that occurs before and after the migration itself takes place. It will discuss how we built a cross-departmental team to accomplish the migration and what changes we made to our digital collections workflows and practices as a result of going through the migration process. By focusing on the organizational and institutional changes related to a system migration, rather than the purely technical ones, this presentation will provide insights that are applicable to a range of institutions and contexts.

column5: Atlanta University Center Robert W. Woodruff Library, United States of America
column7: Managing in a Crisis: How an HBCU Library is Adapting Digital and Archival Workflows in a Rapidly Changing World
column9: project management, archival collecting, web archiving, responsive collecting
column10:
I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
Affiliated with an HBCU (Historically Black Colleges and Universities)
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column14: Affiliated with an HBCU (Historically Black Colleges and Universities)
column16: This panel presentation will address how one HBCU-affiliated library, the Atlanta University Center Robert W. Woodruff Library, tackled adjusting archival processes and workflows in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. It will also discuss how the Library is seeking to collect archival collections more responsively and actively in our changing world.
column17: This panel presentation will address how one HBCU-affiliated library, the Atlanta University Center Robert W. Woodruff Library, tackled adjusting archival processes and workflows in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. It will also discuss how the Library is seeking to collect archival collections more responsively and actively in our changing world.
column18:
Located in the historic westside of Atlanta, the Atlanta University Center Robert W. Woodruff Library (AUC Woodruff Library) supports the teaching, learning and research missions of four institutions of higher learning that comprise the world’s largest consortium of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). Like all institutions of higher education, the Library faced a quickly changing landscape with the advent of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020. In addition, the killings of George Floyd and Rayshard Brooks by police and the resulting protests for racial justice highlighted the need to collect born-digital materials related to these historic events. While the Library was already exploring ways to improve digital and archival workflows and be more responsive and time-sensitive in archival collecting efforts, the pandemic and racial justice protests served as catalysts to hasten these efforts.

This panel presentation will consist of three panelists from the AUC Woodruff Library. The presenters will focus on three areas affected by the events in our rapidly changing world. The first topic is the remote management of digital projects. Responding to the pandemic required a quick and agile pivot from managing an onsite digitization program and three different grant projects to staff working remotely while continuing to provide digital services and support. The presenters will provide strategies employed by AUC Woodruff Library staff to continue managing digital projects and programs in a remote environment.

In addition to the general shift to managing digital projects remotely, the Library also had to consider that the events that affect our communities are happening quickly and oftentimes in an ephemeral digital environment. In order to collect and preserve a more complete version of the history of the HBCU campuses and greater Atlanta Community, the AUC Woodruff Library Archives Research Center is developing responsive collection development initiatives. The presentation will discuss the Library’s shift from passive collection development to learning to adapt quickly to the needs of the community and to the events happening in real-time. To increase active engagement with the community, the Library is strategically defining the collection scope as needed and introducing easy-to-use ways of gathering stories and materials in real-time.

The presenters will conclude by providing concrete examples of projects undertaken by AUC Woodruff Library in response to the shifting environment introduced by the pandemic and racial justice protests. First, the Library initiated a project to collect materials documenting the experience of the Atlanta University Center community during the COVID-19 crisis. The presenters will provide detail about the process of promoting the project, collecting the materials and stories, and making them accessible on the institutional repository. A second project using Archive-It to capture web sites, social media posts, and news relating to these events in the AUC community will also be examined. The presenters will cover workflows and issues around realizing these projects and discuss lessons learned and future plans.
column19:
Located in the historic westside of Atlanta, the Atlanta University Center Robert W. Woodruff Library (AUC Woodruff Library) supports the teaching, learning and research missions of four institutions of higher learning that comprise the world’s largest consortium of Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). Like all institutions of higher education, the Library faced a quickly changing landscape with the advent of the COVID-19 pandemic in March 2020. In addition, the killings of George Floyd and Rayshard Brooks by police and the resulting protests for racial justice highlighted the need to collect born-digital materials related to these historic events. While the Library was already exploring ways to improve digital and archival workflows and be more responsive and time-sensitive in archival collecting efforts, the pandemic and racial justice protests served as catalysts to hasten these efforts.
This panel presentation will consist of three panelists from the AUC Woodruff Library. The presenters will focus on three areas affected by the events in our rapidly changing world. The first topic is the remote management of digital projects. Responding to the pandemic required a quick and agile pivot from managing an onsite digitization program and three different grant projects to staff working remotely while continuing to provide digital services and support. The presenters will provide strategies employed by AUC Woodruff Library staff to continue managing digital projects and programs in a remote environment.
In addition to the general shift to managing digital projects remotely, the Library also had to consider that the events that affect our communities are happening quickly and oftentimes in an ephemeral digital environment. In order to collect and preserve a more complete version of the history of the HBCU campuses and greater Atlanta Community, the AUC Woodruff Library Archives Research Center is developing responsive collection development initiatives. The presentation will discuss the Library’s shift from passive collection development to learning to adapt quickly to the needs of the community and to the events happening in real-time. To increase active engagement with the community, the Library is strategically defining the collection scope as needed and introducing easy-to-use ways of gathering stories and materials in real-time.
The presenters will conclude by providing concrete examples of projects undertaken by AUC Woodruff Library in response to the shifting environment introduced by the pandemic and racial justice protests. First, the Library initiated a project to collect materials documenting the experience of the Atlanta University Center community during the COVID-19 crisis. The presenters will provide detail about the process of promoting the project, collecting the materials and stories, and making them accessible on the institutional repository. A second project using Archive-It to capture web sites, social media posts, and news relating to these events in the AUC community will also be examined. The presenters will cover workflows and issues around realizing these projects and discuss lessons learned and future plans.

column7: Enabling Large-Scale Metadata Management Using a Modular, IDE-Based Approach
column9: metadata, software-development, archives, datasets, medical
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: To enable managing metadata on research dataset holdings in a quickly-changing environment with a team comprising developers and data scientists working with librarians, archivists, and contributors, we adopted an "Integrated Development Environment" (IDE) approach built around flexible components in a Docker-based network. This eschews using monolithic software for metadata management.
column17: To enable managing metadata on research dataset holdings in a quickly-changing environment with a team comprising developers and data scientists working with librarians, archivists, and contributors, we adopted an "Integrated Development Environment" (IDE) approach built around flexible components in a Docker-based network. This eschews using monolithic software for metadata management.
column18:
Our work contributes to the creation of an archives of research efforts, reflecting a wide range of genomic, clinical, behavioral, and other research collaborations across a large pediatric research hospital. These research collections come from a variety of domains and are organized to maximize understandability and reproducibility.

Descriptive metadata enrich and enable display of collection file hierarchies across a variety of systems, enabling dataset linking and discovery. Given the size of the collections (each potentially tens of thousands of files and terabytes of data), these metadata need to be both automatically-generated to the extent possible and manually curated.

An extensive requirements-gathering phase, paired with iterative testing of available software (including Oxygen, Altova XMLSpy, and a novel JSON Editor) made clear several challenges for our environment: the use of separate source control repositories for each collection, which enable ongoing contributions directly from researchers, made existing software inapposite; while large collection record sizes resulting from providing item-level descriptions complicated editing workflows.

We noted that, beyond the typical landscape of metadata management, software development workflows often involve and have solved many of these same concerns. With this in mind, we began to think of metadata management as development. Pairing open-source components with custom tooling, we designed an “Integrated Development Environment” (IDE) -- a text editor with custom components and settings -- specifically for metadata management. This modular system supports large-scale batch changes, data validation, and status checks across collections, while remaining easier to support and further develop than other, monolithic software solutions.

column7: “Digital El Diario” and Archival Justice in the Digital Humanities Graduate Classroom
column9: pedagogy, digital humanities, archives, archival justice, Chicanx history
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This presentation offers student and instructor perspectives on archival justice in the DH graduate classroom and the various DH literacies and competencies such a focus enables. In particular, we provide a closer look at the creation of "Digital El Diario," a project that resulted from a discipline-agnostic graduate course.
column17: This presentation offers student and instructor perspectives on archival justice in the DH graduate classroom and the various DH literacies and competencies such a focus enables. In particular, we provide a closer look at the creation of "Digital El Diario," a project that resulted from a discipline-agnostic graduate course.
column18: This presentation offers student and instructor perspectives on the role archival justice can play to enable the exploration of a variety of digital humanities (DH) literacies and competencies in an discipline-agnostic DH graduate course, from exploring computational approaches such as text mining and geospatial analysis, to postcolonial values and feminist collaboration. We will provide a closer look at the creation of Digital El Diario, the project that resulted from the course in Fall 2019, which centered on historical recovery of the Chicanx student movement at a large public university in the historical territory of Aztlan. Based on El Diario de la Gente, the independent newspaper primarily published for and by Chicanx students at the University of Colorado Boulder between 1972 and 1983, the project represents a window into the extraordinary yet complicated history of the Chicanx Rights Movement in Boulder, the state of Colorado, and the world. The authors and editors covered a wide range of topics, including boycotts and protests, the tragic events surrounding Los Seis de Boulder, and the friction between the Chicanx student community and the university administration. The activist newspaper also served as a creative platform for poetry, art, and literature. Digital El Diario aims to highlight that history through five interdisciplinary student readings of the newspaper that employ DH methods, techniques, and values learned in the course. By way of publishing a plain-text corpus of El Diario, we hope others will continue to explore, interrogate, and celebrate the history of Chicanx student activism.

column7: Critical Digital Pedagogy: Building Community Over Zoom
column9: critical digital pedagogy, remote teaching, building community, faculty workshops
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This presentation provides reflections from a Critical Digital Pedagogy workshop that I developed at Macalester College this summer. The two-week intensive gathered over 60 faculty and staff from across campus to discuss such topics as equity, inclusivity, accessibility, trauma-informed teaching, and engaging students within and beyond the current pandemic context.
column17: This presentation provides reflections from a Critical Digital Pedagogy workshop that I developed at Macalester College this summer. The two-week intensive gathered over 60 faculty and staff from across campus to discuss such topics as equity, inclusivity, accessibility, trauma-informed teaching, and engaging students within and beyond the current pandemic context.
column18:
This spring, I developed a Critical Digital Pedagogy workshop inspired by Hybrid Pedagogy and the work of Dr. Alison Langmead and Kate Joranson at the University of Pittsburgh. The two-week intensive gathered over 60 faculty and staff from across Macalester College to collaborate and share ideas about teaching. During our daily gatherings on Zoom, we discussed pedagogical concerns and strategies pertinent to emergency remote teaching and learning, but that we also hope to carry forward beyond the current crisis.

Throughout the engagement, we discussed a range of topics, including active learning, equity, accessibility, anti-racist pedagogies, assessment, trauma-informed teaching, and ways to effectively engage students.

The critical digital pedagogy framework, articulated by Jesse Stommel, Chris Friend, and Sean Michael Morris, necessitates close scrutiny of technology, and this was key to discussing timely ethical and logistical concerns. Building from the premise that technology is flawed, our workshop focused on how we can purposefully and mindfully engage with colleagues and students during a time when we are physically isolated. We talked about the significance of context; the spaces in which we are teaching and learning, as well as the places in which tools are created and disseminated.

This presentation will discuss findings from this illuminating experience. I went into the workshop with the expectation that we would benefit from the content of the readings and the sharing of our collective wisdom. However, we greatly surpassed my expectations in terms of developing a meaningful and safe community in a virtual space.

column7: Hazine: Transforming Middle East Research Through DH
column9: Digital Archives, Digital Humanities, Middle East
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Hazine is an online resource that seeks to function as a repository of writing on repositories. Recognizing that research can be opaque and that the research process itself is often self-taught, Hazine was meant to help acquaint researchers working on the Middle East with archives and how to navigate them.
column17: Hazine is an online resource that seeks to function as a repository of writing on repositories. Recognizing that research can be opaque and that the research process itself is often self-taught, Hazine was meant to help acquaint researchers working on the Middle East with archives and how to navigate them.
column18:
Hazine was started by two Ottoman historians, to provide archives and library guides for researchers working on the Middle East, North Africa, and Islamicate societies. Since ‘relaunching’ in 2018 with Heather Hughes and N.A. Mansour as co-editors, Hazine has continued to provide the research community with archive reviews, but Hughes and Mansour have since reworked the website to be more broadly inclusive of cultural heritage workers and highlight their contributions to research, while also addressing the unique challenges to Islamic and Middle East Studies research. They hope to continue to build the site as an inclusive space where conversations can happen about the research process from all angles.

Two new team members joined Hazine this year, Shabbir Agha Abbas, and Marwa Gadallah. Abbas provides expertise on manuscripts, and their cataloging and digitization. Gadallah’s skills and expertise lie in highlighting the arts and culture scenes of the Middle East, North Africa, and beyond, including visual art and popular culture.

While Hazine has already been highlighting the many digital resources available, Hazine has continued to do so with the intention of supporting research during the pandemic. In our presentation we will discuss how we work to build community, support equitable access to research materials, and platform underrepresented voices in academia and LIS. We will share the ethics that guide our work, particularly in a context where there are often extraction approaches to cultural heritage in the Middle East. We will also discuss the infrastructure and work that makes this project sustainable.

column16: This presentation examines the community activism and archival work in Minneapolis, Minnesota related to anti-police violence against BIPOC. It highlights the work of activist Wanja Kuria, who, after Floyd’s murder, began protesting racism, state-sanctioned violence and documenting the ways in which the Black Lives Matter Movement operates on the ground.
column17: This presentation examines the community activism and archival work in Minneapolis, Minnesota related to anti-police violence against BIPOC. It highlights the work of activist Wanja Kuria, who, after Floyd’s murder, began protesting racism, state-sanctioned violence and documenting the ways in which the Black Lives Matter Movement operates on the ground.
column18:
The murder of George Floyd in May 2020 set into motion a paradigm shift in America. Despite being in the midst of the COVID-19 global pandemic, black activists and a coalition of white and brown allies took to the streets in record numbers, demanding justice for Floyd, and countless other black bodies who fell victim to police brutality and state sanctioned violence. This other global pandemic, racial injustice & perpetual violence against BIPOC, has a long history, and perhaps it was the combination of factors (city-wide lock downs, government mismanagement of COVID-19 mitigation strategies and the video of the murder of Floyd) caused an eruption of community activism.

This presentation examines the community activism and archival work in Minneapolis, Minnesota related to anti-police violence against BIPOC. Specifically, it highlights the work of young black activist Wanja Kuria, who, after Floyd’s murder, began protesting racism, state sanctioned violence and documenting the ways in which the Black Lives Matter (BLM) movement is operating on the ground. A novice in archivist activism, Kuria’s work focuses on the intersectional community response to the dual pandemic threats through art and protest. Kuria navigates these spaces despite financial constraints and, at times, complicated grassroots politics. She considers the ways in which posters, memorials, spoken word, and music compilations frame the protest space. Through interviews, site visits and participant observation, the audience is transported through Kuria’s phone camera (iPhone XR) lens to witness community activism and archiving on the ground and outside of the mainstream media gaze.

column5: Coherent Digital, United States of America
column7: Accelerating Access to Marginalized Materials
column9: marginalized communities, access, artificial intelligence, archives, special collections
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: CLIR’s new partnership with Coherent Digital will create AI-assisted technologies and workflows that will enable institutions holding unique materials documenting marginalized communities to quickly and cheaply capture digital representations, automatically extract searchable metadata, assign a persistent universal identifier, and facilitate ongoing community-based metadata enrichment in response to research interests.
column17: CLIR’s new partnership with Coherent Digital will create AI-assisted technologies and workflows that will enable institutions holding unique materials documenting marginalized communities to quickly and cheaply capture digital representations, automatically extract searchable metadata, assign a persistent universal identifier, and facilitate ongoing community-based metadata enrichment in response to research interests.
column18:
Let’s face it: traditional library cataloging and archival processing is slow and expensive, and many institutions that hold unique materials documenting marginalized communities lack staff with specialized skills. Moreover, when librarians and archivists select collections to describe, their choices may not align with research interests.

A radically new approach is needed to overcome these obstacles. An approach that puts researchers and the public first, enabling them to inform processing prioritization, contribute to description and tagging, and share their discoveries. An approach that enables institutions to engage staff with little training, and leverage those at others who have relevant expertise by involving them in geographically distributed, virtualized work teams.

In August 2020, CLIR entered into an agreement with Coherent Digital to develop technologies and workflows to achieve these goals and help CLIR fulfill its vision “to promote a coherent digital environment that allows for the robust interoperability of all facets of academic knowledge organization and management as a public good.” Coherent Digital was founded in 2019 by Stephen Rhind-Tutt, co-founder and president of Alexander Street Press.

This Learn@DLF tutorial will introduce the concepts and platform that Coherent Digital has been developing and already deploying in its Policy Commons offering, the world’s largest aggregation of public policy documentation and research. It will also preview tools to capture digital representations of unique materials, leverage AI-assisted technologies to automatically extract searchable metadata, assign a persistent universal identifier, and facilitate ongoing community-based metadata enrichment in response to research needs and usage.

column35: We anticipate that the technologies and workflows discussed in this presentation will be used to support CLIR's HBCU initiatives.
column50: Chuck Henry encouraged us to submit a proposal as a way of helping the DLF community to become aware of CLIR's new partnership with Coherent Digital and its anticipated benefits.

column16: This discussion panel highlights “emulation-in-action” within the EaaSI Network - a distributed, community-driven architecture that supports the exchange of software and configured emulation environments between institutions. Brief demonstrations followed by facilitated discussion will explore three distinct emulation use cases: electronic music composition, videogames, and social science data.
column17: This discussion panel highlights “emulation-in-action” within the EaaSI Network - a distributed, community-driven architecture that supports the exchange of software and configured emulation environments between institutions. Brief demonstrations followed by facilitated discussion will explore three distinct emulation use cases: electronic music composition, videogames, and social science data.
column18:
Yale University Library’s Scaling Emulation and Software Preservation Infrastructure (EaaSI) program of work (funded by the Sloan and Mellon Foundations) proposes a panel with representatives from organizations participating in the EaaSI Network to share “emulation in action.” Each panelist will provide a five-minute demonstration of a computing environment that corresponds to an important emulation use case for their organization. These brief demonstrations will be followed by a moderated discussion that includes prepared questions and an open call for questions from the audience. Presenters from University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (electronic music composition software), Swinburne University of Technology (video games), and Stanford University (social science data) will be asked to describe the evolution of their specific use cases, cross-departmental emulation workflows, and the relevance of their use case environments to their collections and user communities.

Discussion Questions:

What does the process of environment creation look like?

Which staff members or functional areas consulted/contributed to the creation of the environment?

What have you learned about your organization and the impact of software curation on your policies and workflows?

Which/Whose existing needs or requests are being prioritized for emulation and why, and what do these user communities want to do with these environments?

What has the response to emulation been among researchers at your institution? If none, how do you plan to raise awareness and educate researchers on the usefulness of emulation?

column16: This tutorial will teach the basics of using the open-source mapping program QGIS to georeference digitized maps along with publishing these maps using the software development platform GitHub and the mapping platform Mapbox.
column17: This tutorial will teach the basics of using the open-source mapping program QGIS to georeference digitized maps along with publishing these maps using the software development platform GitHub and the mapping platform Mapbox.
column18: This tutorial outlines how we created a basic website that provides access to planning documents from the early 1990s using the Jekyll theme Flaneur on GitHub and Mapbox. These planning documents are historically significant and feature richly descriptive maps of Los Angeles planning areas along with additional textual information about these zones which deal with issues of housing insecurity and abandonment, unemployment, and economic segregation amongst other areas of socio-economic interest. One of the challenges of working with the planning documents was scanning, georeferencing, and then hosting the georeferenced TIFF files through a digital portal. The tutorial will walk through the basics of the process and provide access to documentation and materials for doing it yourself. All software and tools for this project were free to use and the scanner used to digitize the materials was a standard office scanner, cutting down on costs and making map publishing an accessible opportunity for librarians and other researchers to pursue.

column50:
The product of the tutorial can be found at this link: https://visualizela.github.io/planningdocs/
For some context, the workflow and website were the results of an internship between myself and Andy Rutkowski at USC's Library for International & Public Affairs.

column5: Michigan State University
column7: Managing Knowledge Across a Large and Distributed Team: Collapse and Rebirth: A Living Archive on the USSR’s Transformation into 15 Independent States (1985-1994)
column9: archive, metadata, project management, digitization, narrative
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This panel will explore the knowledge management tools and practices necessary to our work of the Collapse and Rebirth project, a publicly accessible archive of materials related to the emergence of the post-Soviet states. Our team's perspectives include faculty, librarians, and students, during the transition from prototype to production.
column17: This panel will explore the knowledge management tools and practices necessary to our work of the Collapse and Rebirth project, a publicly accessible archive of materials related to the emergence of the post-Soviet states. Our team's perspectives include faculty, librarians, and students, during the transition from prototype to production.
column18:
The project is building a publicly accessible archive which includes representative newspaper issues and stories from the various Soviet republics, audio and visual media, prepublication manuscripts from the period, oral interviews with key participants, and curated material from crowdsourcing as well. The project is designed to meet the needs of different kinds of readers: descriptive materials for general readers; instructions for students and teachers who want to use the archival material to write their own “stories”; and for specialists a back end of hard-to-find newspaper accounts, unpublished biographical materials and rare political ephemera, as well as bibliographic resources.

The project is led by a senior scholar who witnessed many of the events featured in the project, and includes librarians at multiple institutions in crucial roles, as well as actively involved graduate and undergraduate students in project implementation, decision-making and management.

This panel discussion will explore the types of knowledge management necessary to the project’s work, and the tools and practices that have served us well as we move from prototype to production. Specifically:

* Dr. Martha Olcott (faculty team lead) will discuss the knowledge management difficulties inherent in creating a digital archival collection from disparate sources, while trying to insure that the long-disadvantaged national, ethnic, and religious communities that made up the USSR are given sufficient voice in the project. She will discuss how we secured donations of material and/or permission to digitize content from multiple institutions, and what practices are emerging for her and her team to sort through and prioritize content.

* Megan Kudzia (digital scholarship librarian) will discuss development of the project's map functionality, especially any modifications made to the Neatline beta plugin for Omeka S, and the technical next steps for developing the project. Finally she will discuss the final research product at MSU Libraries, and our current plans for a long-term home for the project and collections.

* Keelyn O’Brien (graduate student) will talk about developing the educational plugin: what we hope to do, where we are so far, what challenges we’ve run into, and next steps.

* Sofia Cupal (MSU graduate), with contributions from Michael Downs (graduate student), will discuss the development of metadata best practices, as well as the steep learning curve for developing project workflows for digitization, description, and project management. She will also address the difficulties of navigating copyright for this project.

column7: Beyond Captions: The Role of Audio Descriptions & Transcripts in Video Accessibility
column9: accessibility, video, transcripts, audio description, inclusion
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: As video content increases in importance online and in digital collections, it is vital that this content be accessible. While captions are the best known accessibility feature for videos, audio description and transcripts are important to include all users. This presentation will introduce these features and workflows for their creation.
column17: As video content increases in importance online and in digital collections, it is vital that this content be accessible. While captions are the best known accessibility feature for videos, audio description and transcripts are important to include all users. This presentation will introduce these features and workflows for their creation.
column18: As video content increases in importance online and in digital collections, it is vital that this content be accessible. Captions are a fairly well-known element of video accessibility, but even captioned videos can exclude users who are blind or deafblind. To meet the needs of all users, videos may need captions, audio descriptions, and transcripts. In order to ensure that video content is inclusive, it is important to evaluate which accessibility features are needed and offer them with video content. This presentation will introduce the use cases for each of these features and provide guidance on developing workflows for their development. It will also introduce tools and services for their creation.

column7: Subjects that Matter: A Study of LGBTQ Identities in Archive Description
column9: queer theory, subject headings, archives, digital humanities, LGBTQ
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: This presentation will cover my survey of queer identities in subject headings in a dataset of 7,100 EAD files from OCLC’s ArchiveGrid using a combination of text analysis techniques, exploring the relationship of archival description, naming, and the difficulties and potential outcomes of treating archives as data.
column17: This presentation will cover my survey of queer identities in subject headings in a dataset of 7,100 EAD files from OCLC’s ArchiveGrid using a combination of text analysis techniques, exploring the relationship of archival description, naming, and the difficulties and potential outcomes of treating archives as data.
column18: As scholars work to interrogate how classification systems marginalize certain identities and communities, new opportunities emerge to critically explore naming in archival description as a matter of social justice, access, and usage. Building on the work of scholars like Emily Drabinski, Hope Olson, Melissa Adler, and Gracen Brilmyer who examine specific uses and histories of naming in Library of Congress subject headings on gender, sexuality, and ability, I explore the topic of archival description and LGBTQ identity at scale. In this presentation, I will outline my survey of subject headings in a dataset of approximately 7,100 EAD files collected through keyword searches from OCLC’s ArchivesGrid using a combination of text analysis techniques with AntConc, Voyant Tools, and XQueries. Generated from keywords related to LGBTQ identities, I use “queer” as a case study to trace the word across the corpus to investigate similarities, differences, and discrepancies in archival description and LGBTQ identities. While I am interested in locating and mapping queer terminology, I pair this analysis with tracing instances of hate speech and outdated terminology across the corpus. By looking at networks of LGBTQ terminology, I explore the role of subject headings in archival description to represent, label, and, perhaps, mislabel queer identities and subjects. By outlining how this survey joins the work of scholars like Thomas Padilla who explore “archives as data,” I will discuss the difficulties and potential outcomes of utilizing digital humanities methods to consider questions of scale across institutions and encoding standards.

column5: Montana State University, United States of America
column7: Auditing Algorithms: A Case Study for #AlgorithmicAwareness Through Analysis of the YouTube Recommendation Algorithm
column9: Digital Literacy, Algorithms, Text Analysis, Digital Transparency, Teaching
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: What are algorithms and how can we audit them? This session introduces an "algorithmic awareness" teaching module and a generic code application for auditing the algorithms shaping our digital experiences. Our case study will be the YouTube video recommendation algorithm which has come under criticism for its tactics.
column17: What are algorithms and how can we audit them? This session introduces an "algorithmic awareness" teaching module and a generic code application for auditing the algorithms shaping our digital experiences. Our case study will be the YouTube video recommendation algorithm which has come under criticism for its tactics.
column18: Our [Institution], with grant funding from the Institute of Museum and Library Services, has conducted research in order to develop software tools and a standard curriculum to support the teaching of "Algorithmic Awareness": an understanding around the rules that govern our software and shape our digital experiences. With this session, we are looking to introduce a new teaching module for algorithm auditing practices using code, web scraping methods, and structured data analysis to uncover proprietary algorithms. (Code is available in our [Institution] GitHub repository.) Our case study for the module will be the YouTube Video Recommendation Algorithm which has come under criticism for its tactics in drawing parents’ and childrens’ attention to their videos. Our goal will be to show the generic patterns, data points, and scripts one can use to analyze algorithms and to demonstrate how code can be used to introduce transparency and digital literacies to our students. In the end, attendees will be able to realize actionable steps for teaching about algorithms, gain a sense of the first steps one can take to programmatically audit these systems with code, and take away class activities and exercises for their own instruction.

column7: Pandemic Pivot: How to Take Your Event Online, Reach New Audiences, and Build Even Stronger Communities
column9: community, events, best practices
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: We can’t meet safely in person, but we can still gather to share best practices and build community. Join representatives from the IIIF Consortium, the LD4 Conference planning committee, and CLIR/DLF as they discuss the opportunities and the pitfalls prompted by the pandemic-related cancellation of in-person events.
column17: We can’t meet safely in person, but we can still gather to share best practices and build community. Join representatives from the IIIF Consortium, the LD4 Conference planning committee, and CLIR/DLF as they discuss the opportunities and the pitfalls prompted by the pandemic-related cancellation of in-person events.
column18:
We can’t meet safely in person, but communities are still the center of how we move forward as a sector – we can and must still gather to share best practices and celebrate each other's work. Indeed, the pandemic served for many communities as a forcing function to determine better mechanisms of online participation. While still far from perfectly equitable (particularly on the accessibility front), the organizations represented on this panel were better able to achieve many of their goals and reach broader audiences than they would have otherwise. Likewise, quickly shifting to online meeting modes forced a reexamination of priorities and de facto decision-making practices that often goes into planning for in-person conferences.

Join representatives from the IIIF Consortium, the LD4 Conference planning committee, and CLIR/DLF as they discuss the opportunities and the pitfalls prompted by the pandemic pivot. In March, the IIIF Consortium had to cancel their major annual conference event with typical attendance of roughly 300, and replaced it with an online event in the span of 7 weeks that ended up reaching 1200 attendees from 40 countries. The LD4 Conference shifted from a two-day in-person conference scheduled for May to a virtual event held throughout the month of July with over 1500 attendees from at least 26 countries. And of course, CLIR’s DLF Forum and affiliated events are striving to take equity and inclusion to heart in their shift to online programming, using the online format to foster the same spirit of peer learning, community, and professional development for which they are known.

We intend to inspire attendees to take the lessons these organizations have learned and implement them in their own work, whether that’s hosting virtual department meetings or tailoring programs to the needs of remote students, scholars, and other interested parties.

Panelists will cover logistical questions, including fundamental issues of structure, format, and scheduling (especially given international audiences) to maximize inclusion and participation. Panelists will also discuss what worked for their communities, including successful community engagement efforts, and compelling, low-cost technology platforms, as well as what didn’t work: platform pitfalls, engagement gaps, and accessibility failures. Discussion will also center on areas that need more long-term critical examination, how panelists have thought through efforts to keep momentum going after the event, including ties into other programming and communication channels. Likewise, depending on the ability to do real-time Q&A or online response, panelists are eager for all attendees to join in an open discussion about what works and what doesn’t in terms of building community while apart.

column7: Questioning And Que(e)ring Authority: Learning Ontology Literacy In The Wikiverse
column9: ontologies, wikidata, wikimedia, literacy, structured data
column10: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column11: I/we agree to share this submission under a CC-BY 4.0 license.
column16: Modern life’s information ecosystems of structured data and formalized knowledge representation require critical skills and experience. While information professionals engage with concepts of information literacy, this session proposes the more specific concept of ontology literacy, and uses Wikimedia projects as a site to explore practical applications within this theoretical frame.
column17: Modern life’s information ecosystems of structured data and formalized knowledge representation require critical skills and experience. While information professionals engage with concepts of information literacy, this session proposes the more specific concept of ontology literacy, and uses Wikimedia projects as a site to explore practical applications within this theoretical frame.
column18:
How do we equip learners with the critical skills and practice required for working within the ecosystems of structured data and formalized knowledge representation that compose modern life? While information professionals engage with concepts of information literacy, this session proposes the more specific concept of ontology literacy, and uses Wikimedia projects as a site to explore practical applications within this theoretical frame.

Wikidata is a free and open ontology serving as a central knowledge base for all Wikimedia projects. However, it increasingly also informs external systems operated by the likes of Google, Facebook, and Amazon, widely recognized for their algorithmic black boxes. In contrast, Wikimedia spaces' self-documenting transparency illuminates such socio-technical black boxes, facilitating critical engagement and procedural insight. Wikidata as a ‘democratized’ platform holds the promise of a ‘counter-hegemonic’ ontology; one where objectivity arises at the intersection of multiple, per Haraway: situated, knowledges. However, we find even within Wikidata significant hegemonic dynamics; issues with inclusivity and respect for local and minority knowledge; designed-as-descriptive models unfurling prescriptive power; and users reading ‘truth’ into what was intended only ever to be verifiable.

Analyzing these issues (which similarly beset sociotechnical library systems) by observing Wikidata praxis from a pedagogic-theoretical perspective leads us to propose the concept of ontology literacy to ground knowledge representation in social exigencies rather than political–economic agendas or technological affordances. We argue that ontology literacy can help foster critical understanding of the sociotechnical world and responsible use of knowledge-representation systems in the libraries and beyond.

column16: This presentation introduces participants to folder poetry, a form of creative computation which uses the structure of computer folder organization as a poetic form akin to the sonnet or haiku. Folder poetry is a novel, accessible, and engaging interface for discovery within digital collections.
column17: This presentation introduces participants to folder poetry, a form of creative computation which uses the structure of computer folder organization as a poetic form akin to the sonnet or haiku. Folder poetry is a novel, accessible, and engaging interface for discovery within digital collections.
column18:
This presentation introduces participants to folder poetry, a form of creative computation which uses the structure of computer folder organization as a poetic form akin to the sonnet or haiku. Recognizing the poetics of naming and nesting folders and files can also serve as a playful way to visualize an archival arrangement.

Arriving to this hybrid form from our positions as an artist and a library science student, we propose folder poetry as a novel interface for discovery within digital collections. Folder poetry could work in parallel to other digital humanities initiatives such as GIF IT UP, the annual competition to animate and remix cultural heritage works from digital collectons.

Safiya Noble, author of Algorithms of Oppression writes: “Knowledge of the technical aspects of search and retrieval, in terms of critiquing the computer programming code that underlies the systems, is absolutely necessary to have a profound impact on these systems” (2018, 26). Composing folder poetry not only reframes born-digital folder organization, it also provides an accessible entry point to the use of the command line (terminal). How can digital library practitioners encourage a deeper conceptual understanding of computation as a technique for creative research? What are the organizational regimes imposed on our computers and our library collections, and how can we encounter these with fresh perspectives? How can unconventional activities like composing folder poetry help to engage people from different backgrounds in digital library technologies?
